title: More than 75 girls sent home from school after staff said their trousers were 'too TIGHT'
text:
More than 75 girls sent home from school after staff said their trousers were 'too TIGHT' Some young pupils aged from 11 to 16 were also told their skirts were not long enough, parents claimed Share Comments By Cathrina Hulse 00:05, 28 FEB 2017 News Smiths Wood Sports College (Photo: Google) daily More than 75 girls were sent home from school after staff said their trousers were TOO TIGHT.
Some young pupils aged from 11 to 16 were also told their skirts were not long enough, parents claimed.
Mums of students who were told to go home from Smith’s Wood Sports College said they were due to sit important GCSEs in just nine weeks.
One parent told the Birmingham Mail that several youngsters were in tears following the order.
Mum Hayley Hudson was at work when she received a call informing her that her 14-year-old daughter Keely Downey was being sent home.
Three Year 9 pupils from Smiths Wood Sports College sent home for wearing trousers that are too tight (Photo: Birmingham Mail) A furious Hayley, from Chelmsley Wood, said: "She has worn the same style of trousers for nearly four years.
"These ones are from New Look as they didn’t have Keely’s size from the school’s official uniform stockist.
“The school expected parents - many of us work full time - to go out and buy new trousers and then take the kids back to school on the same day.
"It’s disgusting. I wouldn’t allow Keely to wear tight trousers.
"It’s school, not a fashion parade."
The school’s website shows a diagram of the required uniform of a plain black skirt of a reasonable length, just above or just below the knee or black, straight-legged, loose-fitting trousers.
Tight trousers or leggings/jeggings are not allowed and are covered with big red crosses.
Angry mother Jodie Patience also hit out at the school. Her daughter is 13 and has been wearing the same style of trousers from the M&S school range for the last three years and, claimed her upset mum, had been assured by the head of year that these were suitable.
She said: “My daughter said the deputy head picked all the girls as they came into school and sent them into a classroom for wrong uniform.
“Then they phoned all the parents to tell them to pick them up and take them home.
“My daughter’s trousers are not leggings or skinny trousers and they’re not cheap - I bought her three pairs at £16 each.”
Jodie claims pupils at the soon-to-be academy were told that ‘boys were being put off studying’ because some of the girls were wearing the incorrect uniform.
Parents were sent a text message before the start of the February half-term warning there would be a uniform check this week.
Jodie who lives on Windward Way said: “They didn’t want to be sent home.
“I’ve now gone out and bought her another pair of the same M&S trousers but in a bigger size so they will be looser.
“But there’s nothing wrong with the ones she has”.
The College is in the process of becoming an academy and joining Fairfax Multi-Academy Trust.
The Mail made repeated attempts to get a comment from Smith’s Wood Sports College, but as we went to press the school had not replied.
